standfirst: Yusuf Sarwar and Mohammed Ahmed, who were reported to police by family member, plead guilty to terrorism offences
headline: Two British men admit to linking up with extremist group in Syria

standfirst: First British clergyman to enter gay marriage says he is considering legal action after Church blocked attempt to take up new post
headline: Chaplain accuses Church of England of homophobia

standfirst: Zoo says it will be able to confirm pregnancy within 20 to 30 days and anticipates a potential birth in late August
headline: Giant panda Tian Tian has conceived, Edinburgh zoo announces

standfirst: Film will be part of a major first world war digitisation project for the Imperial War Museum
headline: Public will see 1918 footage of George V visiting airbase for first time

standfirst: Public sector workers are staging a nationwide one-day strike over pay, pensions, jobs and spending cuts
headline: Public sector strike - in pictures

standfirst: Passengers must ensure electronic devices are charged before boarding but airlines say this should not mean longer delays
headline: Airport security checks: what do they mean for passengers?

standfirst: Incident occured in village of Cherry Willingham, near Lincoln, and involved train heading for Immingham docks
headline: Two people killed by freight train at footpath crossing

standfirst: Rockets target city for first time since Israel's 2012 war with Hamas, prompting  thousands of residents to seek shelter
headline: Bomb shelters prepared in Jerusalem after rockets are fired from Gaza

standfirst: Commonwealth War Graves Commission puts 300,000 original documents online for public viewing for the first time
headline: New websites to help families find graves of first world war dead

standfirst: The archbishop of Canterbury plans to force legislation through if the General Synod does not accept female bishops
headline: Church of England women bishops: archbishops will overrule synod

standfirst: With 1m British visitors worth an estimated €800m a year, businesses are reluctant to deter funseekers
headline: Magaluf's debauched reputation looks set to stay despite pledge to crack down

standfirst: We asked Muslim bloggers to tell us their experiences of living as a Muslim in the UK today. Do you agree? Share your thoughts and experiences.
headline: What is it like to be a Muslim in Britain today?

standfirst: Police given crucial logs about Diego Garcia's role in rendition programme when it was allegedly used as a secret prison
headline: Emails shed new light on UK link to CIA 'torture flights'

standfirst: More questions surface over the use of Diego Garcia atoll for secret CIA flights to 'black sites'
headline: Remote Indian Ocean island holds key to understanding UK role in rendition

standfirst: Revelation contrasts markedly with White House efforts to distance itself from UK government pressure to destroy disks
headline: NSA chief knew of Snowden file destruction by Guardian in UK

standfirst: Budget airlines say they do not expect new rules to have any effect on passengers taking short-haul flights within Europe
headline: EasyJet and Ryanair passengers 'unlikely to face new security checks'

standfirst: US authorities have announced enhanced security measures, but the TSA's power at airports outside the US may be limited
headline: How much authority does the TSA have over foreign airports?

standfirst: Vasili Mitrokhin's demand granted 20 years on as 2,000 pages of notes he made from KGB archives begin to be made public
headline: Soviet files: KGB defector's cold war secrets revealed at last

standfirst: Case brought by alliance of privacy groups to be heard by IPT, the security services oversight body that normally deliberates in private
headline: NSA surveillance data: UK access to information faces legal challenge

tags: Court of justice of the European Union
standfirst: Move has been prompted by a judicial review claim in the high court that current practice is unlawful
headline: Emergency surveillance law to be brought in with cross-party support

standfirst: All air passengers must demonstrate that mobiles and other devices are powered up and functioning as Department for Transport tightens airport security
headline: Britain follows US in banning powerless electronic devices from flights

standfirst: Rights groups say claim that records of Diego Garcia flights  are missing due to water damage 'smacks of cover-up'
headline: Files on UK role in CIA rendition accidentally destroyed, says minister

standfirst: Report into January's crash near Cley finds bird strike rendered pilot and co-pilot unconscious
headline: Geese 'caused fatal US air force helicopter crash' in Norfolk

standfirst: Ex-husband of Iqbal al-Hilli died of a heart attack in the US on the same day as deadly 2012 attack in French Alps, police say
headline: Alps shootings: murdered woman's 'secret' ex-husband died on same day

standfirst: Legislation aims to shore up powers requiring phone and internet companies to retain and hand over data to security services
headline: Surveillance law wins cross-party support but critics claim stitch-up

standfirst: The transport secretary announces changes to airport security rules in which some passengers on unspecified routes will be required to prove that mobile devices are in working order. Patrick McLoughlin says people must co-operate with the new measures to keep delays to a minimum. The tightening of security comes in response to a 'credible threat' announced by the US Transportation Security Administration
headline: New airport security measures: 'co-operation will reduce delays' - video

standfirst: From surveillance laws and Brazil's destiny to early erotic graffiti and Britons falling off their bikes – a roundup of the week's news
headline: 10 things we learned this week

standfirst: The prime minister says the security services need to listen to someone's phone and read their emails to stop terrorist plots; to do this the government relies on help from internet and telephone companies. The new laws he introduces strengthen their powers to do this, he says, and will also help in the fight against child abuse and other serious crimes. He says he 'will not  stand by' and watch foreign companies become less willing to share private information with the government
headline: David Cameron explains why new surveillance laws are needed and what they will allow – video

standfirst: Prime minister offers review of intercept legislation to secure cross-party support for emergency surveillance laws
headline: David Cameron makes concessions to rush through snooping law

tags: Court of justice of the European Union
standfirst: Plan to require telecoms firms and ISPs retain data is result of 'secret deal between party leaders' and has 'no legal basis'
headline: Emergency surveillance legislation is stitch-up, campaigners say

standfirst: Winner of the vote cannot be declared until election organisers finish checks following allegations of voting fraud
headline: Ashraf Ghani takes million-vote lead in Afghan presidential poll

standfirst: Politicians say a statue of Mahatma Gandhi will be unveiled in Parliament Square in London. In India to meet the country's new prime minister, they say the statue will be a 'monument of the friendship between Britain and India' and say his  lessons of peace between communities and non-violent protests are as relevant today as they were in his own time. Britain will put up a statue to the father of the world's largest democracy in 'the most prominent place that we can'
headline: George Osborne and William Hague announce new statue of Gandhi during visit to India – video
